Award.AwardTitle: Building a Common Framework for Understanding the Dimensions of Achromatic Perception: Brightness, Lightness and Perceived Illumination

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Determining the basic mechanisms of human achromatic visual perception is important to understanding the operation of human vision as a whole. This proposal is concerned with lightness, brightness and transparency perception, and is aimed primarily at understanding how the visual system parses incoming patterns of light into separate representations of surface reflectance and illumination intensity. The research could have implications for the design of visual displays, virtual reality systems, artificial vision systems, and effective lighting systems. The project integrates the basic research goals with the training of undergraduate students as well as public outreach in the state of North Dakota.

Though the initial visual information entering the visual system is a distribution of light intensity (an image) on the back surface of the eye (the retina), the retinal image itself is inherently ambiguous because the intensity at each point in the retinal image is given by the product of the amount of incident light (illumination) and the surface reflectance. Without additional information (or prior assumptions), the relative contributions of these causes cannot be uniquely determined. This is known as the "inverse problem" in vision. The goal of the proposed research is to identify the prior assumptions and processing strategies that the visual system uses to solve this problem. In the experiments, observers make apparent intensity (brightness) and apparent reflectance (lightness) matches of surfaces (both rendered and real) under homogeneous illumination and in the presence of visible shadows and transparencies. Both behavioral responses and pupillary responses will be measured. Measuring both brightness and lightness perception under the carefully controlled conditions of the experiments is expected to increase current understanding of how the visual system parses incoming patterns of light into the separable components of surface reflectance and illumination intensity in the computations that enable perceived lighting to occur. The investigators ultimately aim to explain why people often vary in the accuracy of their judgments about lighting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The visual system does not have direct access to either surface reflectance (R) or illumination (I) but only to their product, the luminance (intensity) distribution falling on the photoreceptor array: L(x, y) = I(x, y) R(x, y). The goal of the research project was to identify assumptions and processing strategies the visual system uses in attempting to solve this fundamental inverse problem in the field of visual perception.

A novel theoretical construct, variable apparent reflectance (lightness) judgment difficulty, was investigated to test the idea that lightness task difficulty explains the confusions, paradoxes, and large variability in lightness judgments observed across studies. In other words, the experiments were designed to reveal the strategies employed by naive observers when asked to make apparent reflectance (lightness) and apparent intensity (brightness) judgments under three different levels of lightness task difficulty. The studies operationalized the theoretical construct of lightness task difficulty within a set of stimuli deemed critical by both lightness and brightness researchers and tested the hypothesis that varying degrees of lightness task difficulty affect observer lightness matching strategies. Specifically, using a version of the Adelson checker-shadow stimulus and a blocked instructional design we tested the hypothesis that increasing lightness task difficulty increases the frequency with which naive observers substitute more easily available (but erroneous) sensory-level brightness judgments for more difficult (but correct) inferred-lightness judgments. In addition, the blocked instructional design allowed us to manipulate the naive observer's understanding of the lightness matching task. For example, in the first block of trials naive observers were given standard instructions to "adjust the matching patch to match the reflectance of the test patch (i.e., to look as if it is cut from the same piece of paper as the test patch". Recall that test patches located in different regions of the display varied in the difficulty of this task. In the second block the same observers were asked to "adjust the matching patch to match the brightness of the test patch (i.e., the intensity/amount of light coming from the test patch)." In the third block, the observers were given more information about the lightness matching task. They were instructed, "After carefully considering the lighting conditions in the stimulus (i.e., is there a shadow on the test patch), adjust the matching patch to match the reflectance of the test patch (i.e., to look as if it is cut from the same piece of paper as the test patch)." In a second experiment the naive reflectance (lightness) matching block and the intensity (brightness) matching block were identical but the informed reflectance instructions were expanded to "Adjust the matching patch to match the reflectance of the test patch (i.e., to look as if it is cut from the same piece of paper as the test patch). Note that a shadow does not change the reflectance (color) of the paper you are matching but only its brightness (intensity). Therefore, to match the reflectance of a test patch when it is within the shadow, adjust the matching patch to how the test patch would appear if it was outside the shadow." Examples of the stimulus with and without the shadow were also presented to the observers prior to the matching trials. A third and fourth experiment used the identical procedures as Experiments 1 and 2 but developed and substituted a high dynamic range version of the checker-shadow display. This experiment tested the hypothesis that illumination differences of larger magnitude than the range of reflectances typically observed in homogeneously illuminated scenes cue observers to make inferred-lightness judgments.

These experiments clarified when lightness judgments are based on sensory-level brightness or brightness-contrast judgments, or refer instead to independent judgments of inferred-lightness. The data resolve definitional, methodological, and theoretical confusions that have plagued communication between brightness and lightness research groups and promise to have a large positive impact on the field by bridging the gap between paradigms to allow comparison of data and models on common ground. 

Experiment 5, "Brightness contrast and assimilation:  The effect of contiguous and noncontiguous backgrounds on target brightness" explored target matching luminance as a function of contiguous surround luminance, contiguous surround width, and non-contiguous-surround luminance over a large range of luminance relationships between target, contiguous surround, and non-contiguous surround.  The larger range of luminance relationships and the greater number of observers compared with previous studies clarifies our understanding of the mechanisms underlying brightness contrast and assimilation effects.

There are numerous benefits conferred on society by expanding knowledge of perceptual processing including broad applicability to any area (i.e., science, education, engineering, and communication) that is impacted by the interface between sighted humans and machines of all descriptions. The project integrated basic research goals with both undergraduate and public education.
